Research Paper Cobalt catalyst encapsulated by N-doped carbon for selective hydrogenation of aldehyde to alcohol Heli Pan Writing – original draft Zixuan Li Methodology Qing Ma Data curation Yaxin Zhang Investigation Yan Zheng Data curation Yongjun Gao Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ Key Laboratory of Analytical Science and Technology of Hebei Province, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hebei University, Baoding 071002, China Key Laboratory of Analytical Science and Technology of Hebei Province, College of Chemistry and Materials Science Hebei University Baoding 071002 China Key Laboratory of Analytical Science and Technology of Hebei Province, College of Chemistry and Materials Science, Hebei University, Baoding 071002, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Furfuryl alcohol is an important industrial chemical and an intermediate for the synthesis of other high-value products. Here, an explosion-assisted strategy was developed to synthesize nitrogen-doped carbon-encapsulated cobalt nanoparticles catalyst Co-NC. The selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol can be achieved over Co-NC in aqueous solution successfully. The presence of cobalt nitrate enhanced the explosion process which promoted its decomposition in turn. The high-temperature reduction process accelerated the derivation of carbon nitride into N-containing carbon encapsulating on cobalt nanoparticles. The N-containing coating improves the hydrophilia and catalytic activity of catalyst, thus achieving the selective hydrogenation of aldehydes in aqueous solution. Graphical abstract An explosion-assisted strategy was developed to synthesize N-doped carbon encapsulated cobalt catalyst that exhibited good catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenation Furfural Cobalt catalyst Nitrogen dopant Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fossil resources provide most of the energy and chemicals for the development of human society. With the high use of valuable fossil resources, energy crisis and environmental problems were becoming increasingly serious [1,2]. It is urgent to develop renewable resources to substitute the valuable and finite fossil resource. Biomass, being composed of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen elements mainly, is abundant and renewable in nature continuously [3–5]. Therefore, to transform the renewable biomass into fine or energy-related chemicals is a promising strategy to relieve the energy and environmental crisis [6,7]. Furfural, an important platform compound in biomass refinery, can be produced with pentosan-rich biomass (such as bagasse, corncob, straw, etc.) as raw materials [8,9], and be transformed into valuable chemicals by selective hydrogenation, such as furfuryl alcohol (FOL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol, cyclopentanone, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran, 2-methylfuran [10–12]. Among these furfural derivatives, FOL is an important chemical, which can be used as food additives, monomer for synthesizing polymers, and intermediates for high-value pesticides and pharmaceuticals [13]. At present, FOL is mainly achieved by selective hydrogenation of furfural. However, in the presence of C=O and C=C bonds [14,15], the over hydrogenation of furfural is inevitable over noble metal catalysts such as Pd [16], Ru [17], and Pt [18,19]. In addition, the high price of precious metal catalysts also restricts the industrial application. It is well known that copper chromate (Cu2CrO4) catalyst has been used in industrial production of FOL because of its high selectivity in FOL production [20]. However, Cr is highly toxic and will cause some pollution to the environment. Therefore, the development of new catalysts with low toxicity, low price and high efficiency for selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol is essential at current stage. Currently, the non-precious transition metal catalysts, such as Co [21,22] and Ni [23], exhibited excellent catalytic activity in hydrogenation. To improve the selectivity to FOL, many strategies, such as functionalizing support, adjusting solvent, bimetals adjustment, were adopted. Among these measures, to functionalize the support is a promising strategy to enhance the catalytic performance of active metal components [24,25]. The appropriate support can not only improve the distribution of active metal component on it, but also adsorb the reactants on the surface of catalyst. Herein, a kind of N-containing carbon-encapsulated cobalt nanoparticle catalyst Co-NC was fabricated through an explosion-assisted strategy with cobalt nitrite and carbon nitride as raw materials [26,27]. The coating of N-containing carbon with abundant oxygen-containing groups on cobalt nanoparticles endows the catalyst with air-resistance ability and ideal hydrophilia. Thus, Co-NC can catalyze the selective hydrogenation of furfural to FOL in aqueous solution with excellent performance. Control experiments and characterizations demonstrate that the special explosion process and nitrogen dopants are key factors to the excellent catalytic performance and selectivity to FOL. The greener reaction conditions, such as aqueous solution and relative low reaction temperature, make the hydrogenation of furfural more sustainable. Besides, the explosion-assisted strategy with urea-derived C3N4 as precursor of nitrogen-containing carbon support for active metals makes the preparation of the supported metal catalyst easier. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, n-dodecane and urea are purchased from Macklin Reagent. p-methyl benzaldehyde, 1-Fluorobenzaldehyde, 2-Fluorobenzaldehyde 3-Fluorobenzaldehyde and 3-hydroxybenzaldehyde are achieved from Energy Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Characterizations The micromorphology of sample was recorded by a transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20). The phase structure and surface components of sample was researched by a powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANCE) and an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250XI). A Raman spectroscope (Lab-RAM HR800, Horiba) equipped with 532 nm laser device was applied to detect the defects of carbon coating. 2.3 Preparation of C3N4 The synthesis of C3N4 was conducted in a muffle furnace in air with urea as raw materials. In general, a covered crucible containing urea (10 g) was wrapped with aluminium foil carefully, so that more product can be achieved after the crucible was calcined at 500 °C in muffle furnace for one hours. In addition, to synthesize a nitrogen-free control sample, glucose was selected as raw materials and carbonized in a muffle furnace under same conditions. 2.4 Preparation of Co-NC An aqueous solution of 3.5 mL containing Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (0.4997 g) was dropped onto C3N4 (0.5 g) powder evenly. The resulting mixture was further ultrasonicated for 5 min to ensure the cobalt component was well distributed in C3N4. Then the mixture was dried at 80 °C in an air dry oven. The dried sample was pink powder and named Co(NO3)2/NC. The sample Co(NO3)2/NC was charged into a quartz tube that can be flowed nitrogen or hydrogen atmosphere (40 mL/min). The sample in quartz tube was then heated in a tube furnace with a ramp of 10 °C /min. At about 280 °C, the mixture was rapidly pyrolyzed into grayish green powder which was named Co-NC-280. Then Co-NC-280 was collected into a quartz tube, continuously heated to 450 °C under hydrogen atmosphere (40 mL/min) and maintained it at this temperature for one hour. The obtained product was labeled Co-NC-450. If nitrogen gas was flowed instead of hydrogen gas, the achieved sample was Co-NC-450-N2. As a control experiment, (CH3COO)2Co was used as a cobalt precursor to replace Co(NO3)2, and no rapid decomposition occurred during the heating process. The product was named CoOACNC-450. At the same time, a cobalt catalyst supported on nitrogen-free carbon material was prepared by using glucose-derived carbon as support, named Co-G-450. In addition, a cobalt catalyst named Co-AC-450 was prepared with activated carbon as support. If C3N4 was prepared with melamine as raw materials, there is no explosion during the heating process and the final product was named Co-MEL-450. 2.5 Catalytic hydrogenation of furfural Generally, furfural (1 mmol), catalyst (7.8 mg) and water (2 mL) are successively added into a autoclave manufactured using 316 stainless steel. High-pressure hydrogen (1.5 MPa) was charged to purge the residual air three times after the autoclave was sealed, and maintained at this pressure. Then put the autoclave into a metal heating mold at 110 °C. After reaction, dodecane (50 µL) was weighted into the reactor as an internal standard and ethanol (15 mL) was used to homogenize the reaction system. After the catalyst was filtered out, the filtrate was analyzed by a gas chromatography (GC, Agilent 7820A, HP-INNOWAX capillary column). 2.6 The in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectrum (DRIFTS) research The in-situ DRIFTs were measured on a NICOLET is-10 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer equipped with a set of Harrick diffuse reflectance accessory. Generally, the sample was reduced at 450 °C in hydrogen flow (30 ml/min) for 30 min firstly. After the temperature was cooled down to room temperature, nitrogen flow (30 ml/min) was switched to sweep the cell for 30 min. Then, a background spectrum was collected for the following analysis. By switching a four-way valve, the furfural gas was carried into the sample compartment for 30 min. Next, pure nitrogen flow was switched to clean the furfural gas in the cell and the spectra was begun to recorder at different time intervals. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Explosion-assisted synthesis and structure of catalyst The urea-derived C3N4 is a kind of light-yellow powder with a floppy structure, which can absorb the solution of cobalt nitrate plenarily. After cobalt nitrate was loaded on the urea-derived C3N4, the achieved sample Co(NO3)2/NC was heated in a quartz tube and an explosion occurred at about 280 °C because of the thermal decomposition of cobalt nitrate on C3N4. The explosion process can be observed clearly according to the video presented in the Fig. S1. In order to achieve the metal cobalt nanostructure in the final product, the achieved sample Co-NC-280 was thermally reduced at 450 °C in hydrogen flow for one hour. Then, the final black catalyst Co-NC-450 was achieved. According to the elemental analysis, the cobalt content in Co-NC-450 reached to 80 wt%. However, if melamine-derived C3N4 was used instead of urea-derived C3N4, no explosion occurred during the heating process. The relative harder structure of melamine-derived C3N4 than urea-derived C3N4 results maybe the main reason for this property. The phase evolutions of cobalt species and C3N4 during the synthesis of catalyst were investigated by XRD (Fig. 1 a). The urea-derived C3N4 possesses the characteristic diffraction peaks of graphitized carbon nitride of (100) and (002) facets situating at 13° and 27.4 ° For the XRD pattern of sample Co-NC-280, the specific diffraction peaks of carbon nitride can still be observed but the intensity decreased extensively, indicating that the explosion process did not completely destroy the crystal structure of carbon nitride. Because there is no specific diffraction peaks of cobalt nitrite or other cobalt species, the cobalt nitrate must be decomposed and cobalt species are well dispersed on the support. However, there are two types of metal cobalt crystalline phase in the sample Co-NC-450 according to XRD result. The XRD pattern of Co-NC-450 shows characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ= 41.6°, 47.6° and 76°, corresponding to the (100), (101) and (110) lattice plane of hexagonal cobalt. While the characteristic diffraction peaks locating at 2θ = 44.2 ° (111), 51.5 ° (200), and 75.9 ° (220) belong to the diffractions of cubic cobalt. The disappearance of the characteristic diffraction peaks of C3N4 indicates that carbon nitride underwent decomposition during the reduction process in hydrogen atmosphere at high temperature. However, the decomposition temperature of C3N4 is higher than 450 °C according to some literatures [28,29]. So, we conclude that the presence of cobalt promoted the transformation of the urea-derived C3N4 to nitrogen-doped carbon. As control sample, Co-G-450 shows a diffraction peak at 2θ = 26.6 ° being ascribed to the graphitized carbon (002) lattice. The diffraction peak of metal cobalt in the XRD pattern of Co-G-450 is sharper than in Co-NG-450, indicating that the crystallinity of metal cobalt nanoparticles in Co-G-450 is better (Fig. 1b). While sample Co-MEL-450 exhibits the characteristic diffraction of Co3O4 except the ones of metal cobalt (Fig. 1b). The Raman spectra (Fig. S2) of two samples Co-NG-450 and Co-G-450 show the effects of N dopants on the structure of carbon components. The D band at around 1590 cm−1 arises from the defects or disorders embodied in the honeycomb-like carbon framework of carbon, while G band locating at 1340 cm−1 is resulted from the Raman-allowed E2g optical phonon, representing the basic vibrating mode of graphitic carbon framework. Thus, the ratio value of D band intensity to G band intensity (ID/IG) can reflect the defects in carbon materials. For the sample Co-NC-450, the value of ID/IG is 0.971, higher than the value (0.763) of Co-G-450, resulting from the N dopants in the carbon lattice. The morphology of Co-NC-450 is researched by using TEM (Fig. 2 ). In the TEM image of Co-NC-450, it can be observed that the cobalt nanoparticles are encapsulated by a layer of carbon, which can protect the cobalt nanoparticles from being oxidized in air (Fig. 2a). The average size of cobalt nanoparticle is about 25 nm. The lattice distance of 0.20 nm is evidently observed in HRTEM image, being ascribed to the (111) lattice in metallic cobalt exactly. And the width of 0.25 nm corresponds to the (111) crystal plane of cobalt oxide exactly, suggesting the partially oxidation of cobalt nanoparticles. XPS analyses were conducted to study the chemical composition and elemental valence states on the surface of Co-G-450, Co-MEL-450 and Co-NC-450 (Fig. 3 ). As shown in the Fig. 3a, Co-G-450, Co-MEL-450 and Co-NC-450 exhibit four peaks at binding energies of 285 eV, 400 eV, 532 eV and around 793 eV, corresponding to elements C, N, O and Co. The nitrogen signal of Co-G-450 is weaker, which may come from the decomposition of cobalt nitrate. The C1s spectra of Co-G-450, Co-MEL-450 and Co-NC-450 show main peaks locating at 284.8 eV, suggesting that the carbon component in the three samples is mainly graphic carbon (Fig. 3b). The ratio of carbon species binding to oxygen element in Co-NC-450 is higher than in Co-G-450 and Co-MEL-450 according to the fitting results of C1s spectra, which would improve the hydrophilia of Co-NC-450. The contact angle measurement was conducted with water to prove the better hydrophilia of Co-NC-450 than Co-G-450 (Fig. S3). The smaller contact angle of Co-NC-450 (13.1°) than that of Co-G-450 (112°) suggested that Co-NC-450 can contact with water better than Co-G-450, which is favor of improving the catalytic activity of Co-NC-450 in aqueous solution. The N1s profiles of Co-NC-450 and Co-MEL-450 can be deconvolved into four peaks, corresponding to C=N-C (398.4 eV), Co-N (399.8 eV) and tertiary nitrogen (401.9 eV) respectively (Fig. 3c) [30], suggesting the partial structure reservation and evolution of C3N4 during the reduction in hydrogen atmosphere. For the sample Co-G-450, the deconvolved peak at 398.4 eV can be ascribed to the amino group that may be generated from the reduction process. The Co-N component locating at 399.8 eV, which is in accordance with Co-NC-450 and Co-MEL-450. The fitted peak with higher binding energy of 401.9 eV can be assigned to the protonized amino groups [31]. The coordination between Co and nitrogen on support can reduce the aggregation of Co nanoparticles so that improve the dispersion of cobalt, which is beneficial for improving the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst. Besides, nitrogen dopants can improve the conductivity of carbon material and change the electronic structure, which is conducive to promoting the electron transfer between metal and carrier, thereby improving the catalytic performance [32]. For XPS Co2p spectra (Fig. 3d), the two peaks at 778.2 eV and 793.1 eV can be ascribed to metallic cobalt. The peaks at binding energy of 780.2 and 795.4 eV correspond to Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 of CoO, and the deconvolved peaks at 782.5 and 779.6 eV can be classified as the characteristic peaks of Co 2p3/2 and Co2p1/2 in Co-N component. This special configuration can improve the electronic structure so that enhance the catalytic performance. Meanwhile, peaks with binding energies between 786.0 and 802.5 eV are considered satellite peaks caused by vibration [33]. These results indicate that the metal cobalt was oxidized in air during sample preparation for XPS measurement. 3.2 Catalytic performance The selective hydrogenation of furfural was selected as probe reaction to evaluate the catalytic application of the cobalt-based catalysts in biomass conversion. Under 1.5 MPa hydrogen atmosphere and with water (2 mL) as solvent, 1 mmol furfural can be hydrogenated to FOL completely. In contrast, the conversion of furfural can only reach to 78 % and the selectivity to FOL is only 90 % over catalyst Co-G-450 under the same reaction conditions (Fig. 4 a), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol is a main side product. With activated carbon as support, the achieved catalyst Co-AC-450 can only achieve 15 % conversion of furfural accompanied with 80 % selectivity to FOL. These results illustrate that Co-NC-450 is an excellent catalyst for selectively hydrogenating furfural to FOL, and nitrogen dopants in catalyst is helpful to enhance the catalytic activity. In addition, the catalytic performance of CoOACNC-450 is not ideal although this catalyst was prepared with urea-derived carbon nitride as raw materials. Besides, the catalytic performance of Co-MEL-450 is inferior to that of Co-NC-450. Because CoOACNC-450 was prepared with (CH3COO)2Co as cobalt precursor and Co-MEL-450 was synthesized with melamine-derived C3N4 as support instead of urea-derived C3N4, and there is no explosion process during the whole procedure for preparing catalysts, it demonstrates that the explosion step is important to the excellent catalytic performance of catalyst. According to the temperature-programmed desorption of hydrogen (H2-TPD) after catalysts were reduced in hydrogen atmosphere (Fig. S5), the cobalt dispersions in Co-NC-450, Co-MEL-450 and Co-G-450 are 46.6 %, 36.1 % and 33.1 %, respectively (Table S1). So, the sample Co-NC-450 exhibited the best catalytic performance. As a control, Co-NC-450-N2 exhibited poor catalytic activity because the conversion of furfural was only 21.5 % under the optimal reaction conditions. The XRD and XPS analyses also confirmed that the reduction step in hydrogen was essential for the catalyst Co-NC-450 possessing high catalytic activity in hydrogenation (Figs. S5–7). Unfortunately, the stability of Co-NC-450 is not ideal because the time needed to completely conversion of furfural has to be prolonged along with the recycling runs increase (Fig. 4b). The XRD pattern of Co-NC-450 after reaction shows that the diffraction of graphic carbon disappeared and characteristic diffraction of cobalt oxide appeared (Fig. S4). The partial loss of carbon coat results to the oxidation of active metal cobalt, causing the decrease of catalytic activity of Co-NC-450 during the recycling experiments. The best reaction conditions for furfural hydrogenation over Co-NC-450 was also screened. Firstly, the reaction dynamic was researched. Along with the reaction time increased, the conversion of furfural increased and 100 % conversion of furfural can be obtained at only 2.5 h. It was noting that the selectivity to FOL maintained at high level in the whole process and still maintained even the reaction time was pronged to 3 h. It indicates that Co-NC-450 is an excellent selective hydrogenation catalyst (Fig. 5 a), which results from the well-distribution of cobalt and nitrogen dopants. The reaction temperature was also screened over Co-NC-450 (Fig. 5b). The reaction rate increases along with the increase of reaction temperature and the selectivity to FOL remains high at different temperature. However, if the reaction temperature reaches to 120 °C, the selectivity to FOL is only 90.7 % due to the over-hydrogenation of FOL. Besides, the solvents for this reaction were also screened in order to achieve the optimal reaction conditions, because the solubility of furfural and its hydrogenated product is not good in water. However, it was found that the conversion of furfural and the selectivity to FOL in water were better than in methanol and ethanol, despite the better solubility of organic reactant and product in alcohols (Fig. 5c). Finally, we studied the effect of hydrogen pressure on the catalytic performance of Co-NC-450 under the conditions of reaction temperature of 110 °C and reaction time of 2.5 h. Under the hydrogen pressure of 1.5 MPa, furfural was completely converted and the yield of FOL reaches 100 %. When the hydrogen pressure was 2 MPa, the selectivity to FOL still maintains (Fig. 5d). All these results illustrate that the key factor to determine the selectivity to FOL is reaction temperature. Certainly, the excellent catalytic performance of Co-NC-450 makes the hydrogenation of furfural greener than other catalytic system. We compared the catalytic activity of our experimental catalyst with other catalysts reported in literatures in the hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol (Table S2). It can be seen that our catalytic system is relatively greener than others due to its relative low reaction temperature, short reaction times, aqueous solution and higher conversion and selectivity. Combining the experiments and characterizations, it can be concluded that the cobalt component is responsible for activating hydrogen and the nitrogen-containing carbon contributes to adsorb substrate on the surface of catalyst during the catalytic reaction in aqueous solution. Furthermore, the in-situ DRIFTs were conducted to research the adsorption of furfural on the Co-NC-450 and Co-G-450. As shown in Fig. 6 , the vibration of C=C in furan ring of furfural locates around 1470 cm−1, and the vibration of C=O of aldehyde group in furfural is around 1670 cm−1 [34]. For the sample Co-G-450 adsorbing furfural, the two characteristic vibrations of furfural can be observed clearly. However, if furfural was adsorbed on Co-NC-450, the v(C=O) at 1670 cm−1 disappeared, generating two new vibrations at 1720 and 1570 cm−1. This result reflects the adsorption of C=O on the catalyst Co-NC-450, which may be positive promotion in activating C=O bond in the hydrogenation of furfural [35]. We studied the catalytic activity of Co-NC-450 for hydrogenation of other carbonyl compounds (Table 1 ). For other aldehydes, the hydrogenation reaction can be carried out smoothly by prolonging the reaction time or changing the reaction temperature. For cyclohexanone, the yield of cyclohexanol can reach 99 % after reacting for 3.5 h at 110 °C and 1.5 MPa H2. It showed that the Co-NC-450 has a wide range of applications and can catalyze the hydrogenation of various aldehydes. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a kind of N-containing carbon encapsulated cobalt catalyst Co-NC-450 was prepared by using urea and cobalt nitrate as raw materials. The explosion process was intensified by the cobalt nitrite and in turn facilitated the well-distribution of cobalt species. At the same time, nitrogen dopants promote the electron transfer between metal and carrier, which was conducive to the adsorption and activation of reactants. Thus, the catalyst Co-NC-450 had good catalytic activity and excellent selectivity in catalytically transforming furfural to furfuryl alcohol. This study developed an effective strategy for designing highly efficient transition metal catalysts for selective hydrogenation under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: Furfuryl alcohol is an important industrial chemical and an intermediate for the synthesis of other high-value products. Here, an explosion-assisted strategy was developed to synthesize nitrogen-doped carbon-encapsulated cobalt nanoparticles catalyst Co-NC. The selective hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol can be achieved over Co-NC in aqueous solution successfully. The presence of cobalt nitrate enhanced the explosion process which promoted its decomposition in turn. The high-temperature reduction process accelerated the derivation of carbon nitride into N-containing carbon encapsulating on cobalt nanoparticles. The N-containing coating improves the hydrophilia and catalytic activity of catalyst, thus achieving the selective hydrogenation of aldehydes in aqueous solution.
coredata.dc:title: Cobalt catalyst encapsulated by N-doped carbon for selective hydrogenation of aldehyde to alcohol
